newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish debt/currency market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Swedish debt/currency market closing report.

text.p: Swedish long yields continued to track foreign markets lower on Friday while shorter maturities inched higher and the crown firmed.
"We were on our way to a recoil phase late on Thursday, but nothing came out of it. We've been tracking Italy all day long," one dealer said.
Nine-year bond yields fell eight basis points to 7.39 percent and dealers said the undertone was still quite positive.
The spread between Swedish and German long yields decreased seven basis points to 131.
The shortest maturities, however, climbed a bit and the yield curve flattened further.
"People are selling short-term mortgage bonds, which have put pressure on the short end of the curve. There is probably some profit-taking," one dealer said.
Behind the profit-taking was the fact that Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, has slowed its pace of cutting the repo rate and in the short term the curve could flatten more.
"The Future Rate Agreements show that the market obviously is not discounting so many more cuts," he added.

One chief dealer said another reason the curve was flattening could be the Riksbank's decision to intensify its currency dealing. This could have a negative impact on shorter yields if the Riksbank decides to sell crowns, he said.
"There is some speculation that the Riksbank is building up its currency reserve ahead of (a possible link to) Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism," he said.
The crown firmed to 4.3480 against the mark compared to 4.3650 late on Thursday.
